1980.headline: The world confronts polio as a global threat
1980.stat: ≈350,000 children paralyzed each year in 125+ countries
1980.photo: Portrait of a child using crutches in a clinic courtyard

1981.headline: Brazil shows polio can be stopped
1981.stat: Brazil’s cases plunge to ≈122 after mass NIDs.
1981.photo: Children lined up at a school vaccination booth in Brazil

1982.headline: Campaigns push Brazil’s polio near zero
1982.photo: Health worker marking a child’s finger with ink

1983.headline: Dominican Republic eliminates polio
1983.photo: Crowds at a Dominican Republic immunization day

1984.headline: Finland halts a rare outbreak
1984.stat: Tens of thousands vaccinated within weeks stop spread.

1985.headline: A regional goal and a citizen army
1985.stat: PAHO targets Americas’ eradication by 1990; Rotary launches PolioPlus.
1985.photo: Rotary volunteers administering drops to children

1986.headline: Millions reached in a single year
1986.stat: PolioPlus supports vaccination for ≈150 million children.

1987.headline: Investment and vigilance drive progress
1987.stat: Americas see ≈64% drop in cases after new financing & stronger surveillance.

1988.headline: The world launches the Global Polio Eradication Initiative
1988.photo: Leaders at World Health Assembly announcing initiative

1989.headline: Oman’s outbreak reveals hidden risks
1989.stat: Despite ≥85% routine coverage, cases occur—supplementary campaigns added.

1990.headline: Science builds a global defense
1990.stat: Global Polio Laboratory Network grows to 140+ accredited labs.
1990.photo: Technicians testing samples in a lab

1991.headline: Last indigenous case in the Americas
1991.stat: Peru records the final wild polio case in the region.
1991.photo: Peruvian child holding a vaccination card

1992.headline: Outbreak strikes unvaccinated groups in Europe

1993.headline: U.S. confirms no wild polio circulation
1993.stat: Last imported case recorded; surveillance shows the virus is gone.
1993.photo: Public health workers testing sewage samples

1994.headline: The Americas certified polio-free
1994.stat: China vaccinates ~80 million children in mass campaigns the same era.

1995.headline: India launches massive Pulse Polio Days

1996.headline: Mandela calls to 'Kick Polio Out of Africa'

1997.headline: Last wild polio case in Western Pacific
1997.photo: Map of Western Pacific with Cambodia highlighted

1998.headline: Europe records its final indigenous case
1998.stat: Turkey is last to report wild polio.

1999.headline: The last wild type 2 case is recorded
1999.stat: Final isolate in Bihar, India; serotype later declared eradicated (2015).

2001.headline: Polio shrinks—and reveals a solvable risk
2001.stat: Endemic countries drop to 10; <1,000 global cases; cVDPV appears where immunity is low.

2002.headline: Europe certified polio-free
2002.stat: ≈870M people now live in certified regions.

2003.headline: Vaccination suspensions spark global spread
2003.stat: Suspension in northern Nigeria leads to outbreaks across dozens of countries.

2005.headline: New vaccines target stubborn outbreaks
2005.stat: Monovalent OPVs enable precise outbreak control.

2006.headline: Only four endemic countries remain
2006.stat: Afghanistan, India, Nigeria, Pakistan still harbor polio.

2007.headline: 400M children immunized worldwide
2007.stat: Children reached in 27 countries, including remote Afghan mountains.
2007.photo: Health worker vaccinating a child on mountain paths

2008.headline: Outbreaks spread across West Africa
2008.stat: Importations from Nigeria reignite cases in 20+ countries.

2009.headline: Outbreaks swiftly contained in Central Africa
2009.stat: Rapid mop-up campaigns prevent further spread.

2010.headline: Explosive outbreaks stopped fast
2010.stat: ≈900 cases across Tajikistan & Congo halted within months.

2011.headline: India records its last wild polio case
2011.stat: From 741 cases (2009) to 1 case (2011) in a country of 1.2B.

2012.headline: Last wild type 3 case recorded
2012.stat: Final WPV3 case in Nigeria (Nov); serotype declared eradicated in 2019.

2013.headline: War cannot stop vaccination
2013.stat: 22M children immunized after Syria’s outbreak spread to Iraq.
2013.photo: Aid worker vaccinating a Syrian refugee child

2014.headline: South-East Asia certified; WHO declares global emergency
2014.stat: ≈1.8B people certified wild-polio-free; international spread declared a Public Health Emergency.

2015.headline: Wild polio type 2 eradicated
2015.stat: WPV2 certified eradicated; Nigeria removed from endemic list.

2016.headline: Largest vaccine switch in history
2016.stat: 150 countries switch from trivalent to bivalent OPV within weeks.

2017.headline: Vaccine-derived outbreaks outnumber wild polio
2017.stat: Wild polio drops to 22 cases; cVDPV appears where immunity is low.

2018.headline: Nigeria nears elimination; data speeds response
2018.stat: Two years without wild polio; cVDPV outbreaks test systems.
2018.photo: Health worker using a mobile app for surveillance

2019.headline: Wild polio type 3 eradicated
2019.stat: Second wild strain wiped out worldwide.

2020.headline: Africa certified free of wild polio—amid COVID-19
2020.stat: ≈1.8B people live in a region certified wild-polio-free; door-to-door briefly paused then adapted.

2021.headline: Novel OPV2 rolls out; Afghanistan resumes nationwide vaccination
2021.stat: nOPV2 used under WHO EUL from March; >100M doses administered; Afghan campaigns restart.

2022.headline: Polio detected in high-income settings
2022.stat: Paralytic case in New York; related virus found in wastewater; poliovirus detected in London sewage.

2023.headline: More cVDPV countries; fewer wild cases; nOPV2 prequalified
2023.stat: WPV1 cases drop to ~12; 8 new cVDPV countries; WHO prequalifies nOPV2; hundreds of millions of doses used.
2023.photo: Map of outbreak countries with vaccine logistics

2024.headline: Dozens of cVDPV outbreaks tracked and tackled
2024.stat: 74 cVDPV outbreaks across 39 countries (Jan 2023–Jun 2024); 600+ AFP cases investigated.
2024.photo: Graph of outbreaks with vaccination tents

2025.headline: Global emergency remains—until we finish everywhere
2025.stat: WHO maintains Public Health Emergency; cross-border spread detected via wastewater.
2025.photo: WHO emergency meeting with wastewater sampling
